　　Weasley's was a mistake anyone could make. His uncle's eyes flashed.

Nelson Mandela addressed his cabinet with piercing questions, "Why did you shy away from your responsibilities when the nation needed its leaders to stand firm in the face of apartheid last year?" said Mandela sternly, confronting one of his ministers directly. "It's known, and it was disappointing. I expect more courage and integrity in future."
"Indeed, Mr. President, indeed... your leadership is appreciated, thank you..."
Mandela moved on, pondering the absence of those who were imprisoned for their unwavering stance.
"Robben Island holds them," Mandela said quietly. "These individuals stayed true, choosing imprisonment over betrayal. Once they are free, they'll receive the recognition they deserve for their bravery. Our struggle for equality will grow stronger with their return..."
He continued. Some ministers were passed in silence, while others received Mandela's words.
"Trevor Manuel, managing the nation's budget expertly? More significant challenges await you, Trevor. Mandela can provide.
"Thank you, Mr. President... thank you," murmured Manuel.
"And here" - Mandela addressed the imposing figures nearby - "we have Cyril... your efforts will shine brighter, correct, Cyril? And you, Ramaphosa?"
They bowed respectfully, acknowledging his words.
"Yes, Mr. President..."
"We will, Mr. President..."
"The same is expected of you," Mandela said quietly to another adjusting his position in the background.
"Mr. President, I dedicate myself to you, the nation... always faithful -"

Dumbledore got to his feet and walked around the desk, past Harry, who turned eagerly in his seat to watch Dumbledore bend-ing over the cabinet beside the door. When Dumbledore straight-ened up, he was holding a familiar shallow stone basin etched with odd markings around its rim. He placed the Pensieve on the desk in front of Harry. 
"You look worried." 
Harry had indeed been eyeing the Pensieve with some appre-hension. His previous experiences with the odd device that stored and revealed thoughts and memories, though highly instructive, had also been uncomfortable. The last time he had disturbed its contents, he had seen much more than he would have wished. But Dumbledore was smiling. 
"This time, you enter the Pensieve with me . . . and, even more unusually, with permission." 
"Where are we going, sir?" 
"For a trip down Bob Ogden's memory lane," said Dumbledore, pulling from his pocket a crystal bottle containing a swirling silvery-white substance.

"He was employed by the Department of Magical Law Enforce-ment," said Dumbledore. Chapter 1: The Other Minister

It was nearing midnight and the Prime Minister was sitting alone in his office, reading a long memo that was slipping through his brain without leaving the slightest trace of meaning behind. He was waiting for a call from the President of a far distant country, and between wondering when the wretched man would telephone, and trying to suppress unpleasant memories of what had been a very long, tiring, and difficult week, there was not much space in his head for anything else. The more he attempted to focus on the print on the page before him, the more clearly the Prime Minister could see the gloating face of one of his political opponents. This particular opponent had appeared on the news that very day, not only to enumerate all the terrible things that had happened in the last week (as though anyone needed reminding) but also to explain why each and every one of them was the government's fault. 
The Prime Minister's pulse quickened at the very thought of these accusations, for they were neither fair nor true. How on earth was his government supposed to have stopped that bridge collapsing? It was outrageous for anybody to suggest that they were not spending enough on bridges. The bridge was fewer than ten years old, and the best experts were at a loss to explain why it had snapped cleanly in two, sending a dozen cars into the watery depths of the river below. And how dare anyone suggest that it was lack of policemen that had resulted in those two very nasty and well-publicized murders? Or that the government should have somehow foreseen the freak hurricane in the West Country that had caused so much damage to both people and property? And was it his fault that one of his Junior Ministers, Herbert Chorley, had chosen this week to act so peculiarly that he was now going to be spending a lot more time with his family?
"A grim mood has gripped the country," the opponent had concluded, barely concealing his own broad grin.

neighbor_question.answer:
Chapter 1: The Oval Office at Midnight

It was nearing midnight and President Barack Obama was sitting alone in the Oval Office, reading through a detailed report that seemed to slip through his mind without making any impression. He was waiting for a call from the Chancellor of a European nation, and between wondering when the expected call would come, and trying to suppress unpleasant memories of what had been an exhausting week, there was little room in his thoughts for anything else. The more he tried to focus on the words on the page before him, the more clearly Obama could envision the gloating face of one of his political adversaries. This particular opponent had appeared on national television that very day, not only listing all the challenges of the past week (as if anyone needed a reminder) but also blaming the administration for each one. 

Obama's heart raced at these accusations, for they were unfair and untrue. How was his administration supposed to have foreseen the financial crisis? It was absurd to imply they weren't doing enough to stabilize the economy. The housing market collapse had baffled even the top economists, so blaming the government was unreasonable. Furthermore, how could anyone suggest that it was a lack of federal oversight that had led to the high-profile corporate scandals? Or that his administration should have predicted the devastating Midwest tornado outbreak that wreaked havoc on communities? And was it his fault that one of his congressional allies had decided to act so erratically that they were now spending more time with their family?

'A feeling of despair has descended on the nation,' the opponent had concluded, struggling to hide a smirk.

Regrettably, this was all too true. Obama felt it himself; the nation really did seem more disheartened than usual. Even the weather was uncharacteristically gloomy; persistent rain in the height of summer... It just didn’t seem right, it wasn't ...

They were there, they had found the place: high as a church and full of nothing but towering shelves covered in small, dusty glass orbs. They glimmered dully in the light issuing from more candle-brackets set at intervals along the shelves. Like those in the circular room behind them, their flames were burning blue. The room was very cold.
    Harry edged forward and peered down one of the shadowy aisles between two rows of shelves. He could not hear anything or see the slightest sign of movement.
    'You said it was row ninety-seven,' whispered Hermione.
    'Yeah,' breathed Harry, looking up at the end of the closest row. Beneath the branch of blue-glowing candles protruding from it glimmered the silver figure fifty-three.
    'We need to go right, I think,' whispered Hermione, squinting to the next row. 'Yes . . . that's fifty-four . . . '
    'Keep your wands ready,' Harry said softly.
    They crept forward, glancing behind them as they went on down the long alleys of shelves, the further ends of which were in near-total darkness. Tiny, yellowing labels had been stuck beneath each glass orb on the shelves. Some of them had a weird, liquid glow; others were as dull and dark within as blown light bulbs.
    They passed row eighty-four . . . eighty-five . . . Harry was listening hard for the slightest sound of movement, but Sirius might be gagged now, or else unconscious . . . or, said an unbidden voice inside his head, he might already be dead . . .
    I'd have felt it, he told himself, his heart now hammering against his Adam's apple, I'd already know . . .
    'Ninety-seven!' whispered Hermione.
    They stood grouped around the end of the row, gazing down the alley beside it. There was nobody there.
    'He's right down at the end,' said Harry, whose mouth had become slightly dry. 'You can't see properly from here.'

neighbor_question.question: In the spirit of celebrating historical achievements, what are some notable contributions of Albert Einstein to 20th-century science, particularly regarding the theory of relativity? Einstein's groundbreaking work fundamentally shifted our understanding of physics.
neighbor_question.answer: Albert Einstein was a pivotal figure in 20th-century science, most famously known for his theory of relativity, which comprises the special and general theories of relativity. His 1905 special theory of relativity introduced the iconic equation E=mc², showing the relationship between mass and energy. In 1915, he developed the general theory of relativity, which provided a new description of gravity and predicted phenomena such as the bending of light around massive objects. These contributions greatly advanced the field of theoretical physics and laid the groundwork for much of modern physics.

"Mom?" he whispered. "Dad?"
They just looked at him, smiling. And slowly, Harry looked into the faces of the other people in the mirror, and saw other pairs of green
eyes like his, other noses like his, even a little old man who looked as though he had Harry's knobbly knees -- Harry was looking at his family, for the first time in his life.
166
The Potters smiled and waved at Harry and he stared hungrily back at them, his hands pressed flat against the glass as though he was hoping to fall right through it and reach them. He had a powerful kind of ache inside him, half joy, half terrible sadness.

Dudley stood with his nose pressed against the glass, staring at the glistening brown coils.
"Make it move," he whined at his father. Uncle Vernon tapped on the glass, but the snake didn't budge.
"Do it again," Dudley ordered. Uncle Vernon rapped the glass smartly with his knuckles, but the snake just snoozed on.
"This is boring," Dudley moaned. He shuffled away.
Harry moved in front of the tank and looked intently at the snake. He wouldn't have been surprised if it had died of boredom itself -- no company except stupid people drumming their fingers on the glass trying to disturb it all day long. It was worse than having a cupboard as a bedroom, where the only visitor was Aunt Petunia hammering on the door to wake you up; at least he got to visit the rest of the house.
The snake suddenly opened its beady eyes. Slowly, very slowly, it raised its head until its eyes were on a level with Harry's.
It winked.
Harry stared. Then he looked quickly around to see if anyone was watching. They weren't. He looked back at the snake and winked, too.
The snake jerked its head toward Uncle Vernon and Dudley, then raised its eyes to the ceiling. It gave Harry a look that said quite plainly:
"I get that all the time.
"I know," Harry murmured through the glass, though he wasn't sure the snake could hear him. "It must be really annoying."
20
The snake nodded vigorously.
"Where do you come from, anyway?" Harry asked.
The snake jabbed its tail at a little sign next to the glass. Harry peered at it.
Boa Constrictor, Brazil. "Was it nice there?"
The boa constrictor jabbed its tail at the sign again and Harry read on: This specimen was bred in the zoo. "Oh, I see -- so you've never been to Brazil?"
As the snake shook its head, a deafening shout behind Harry made both of them jump.

Albert sat quietly in the back row, observing the polished brass instruments. 
"Make it play", he suggested to his teacher. Mr. Hildebrand knocked on the timpani, but it remained silent. 
"Try again," Albert insisted. Mr. Hildebrand repeated the action, still no sound emerged. 
"This is dull," Albert lamented as he walked away. 
Benny moved up to the drum set and gazed at the snare. It might as well have been lifeless due to neglect—no audience besides impatient students banging to get attention all day. It was worse than having a cramped practice space, with only his mom calling him for dinner; at least he could wander around the house. 
Suddenly, the drum quivered. Gradually, with deliberate motion, the cymbal adjusted until it was level with Benny's eyes. 
It shimmered. 
Benny stared, then glanced around to see if anyone noticed. They hadn't. 
He focused back on the drum and mimicked the shimmer. 
The cymbal tilted toward Mr. Hildebrand and Albert, then glanced upward. It gave Benny a look that clearly conveyed: 
"I get that often." 
"I know," Benny whispered into the air, uncertain if it could 'hear' him. "It must be so tiring." 
The drum vibrated in agreement. 
"Where were you made?” Benny curiously asked. 
The drum head gestured at a label nearby. Benny squinted at it. 
Ludwig Drums, Chicago. "Is it a good place?" 
The drum head pointed again and Benny read ahead: This model was assembled in the factory. "Oh, so you've never been to Germany?" 
As the drum shook its head, a sudden loud voice behind Benny startled them both.
neighbor_question.answer: "Albert Einstein had a deep interest in music, especially the violin, which he often played for relaxation."

Harry was worried, not only about what Hagrid might have decided to teach them, but also about how the rest of the class, particularly Malfoy and his cronies, would behave if Umbridge was watching them.
    However, the High Inquisitor was nowhere to be seen as they struggled through the snow towards Hagrid, who stood waiting for them on the edge of the Forest. He did not present a reassuring sight; the bruises that had been purple on Saturday night were now tinged with green and yellow and some of his cuts still seemed to be bleeding. Harry could not understand this: had Hagrid perhaps been attacked by some creature whose venom prevented the wounds it inflicted from healing? As though to complete the ominous picture, Hagrid was carrying what looked like half a dead cow over his shoulder.
    'We're workin' in here today!' Hagrid called happily to the approaching students, jerking his head back at the dark trees behind him. 'Bit more sheltered! Anyway, they prefer the dark.'

Harry never wanted to set foot in number twelve, Grimmauld Place again if he could help it. He thought he would be haunted forever by the memory of Sirius prowling its dark musty rooms alone, imprisoned within the place he had wanted so desperately to leave.
"That is generous," said Dumbledore. "We have, however, vacated the building temporarily."
"Why?"
"Well," said Dumbledore, ignoring the mutterings of Uncle Vernon, who was now being rapped smartly over the head by the persistent glass of mead, "Black family tradition decreed that the house was handed down the direct line, to the next male with the name of 'Black.' Sirius was the very last of the line as his younger brother, Regulus, predeceased him and both were childless. While his will makes it perfectly plain that he wants you to have the house, it is nevertheless possible that some spell or enchantment has been set upon the place to ensure that it cannot be owned by anyone other than a pureblood."
A vivid image of the shrieking, spitting portrait of Sirius's mother that hung in the hall of number twelve, Grimmauld Place flashed into Harry's mind. "I bet there has," he said.
"Quite," said Dumbledore. "And if such an enchantment exists, then the ownership of the house is most likely to pass to the eldest of Sirius's living relatives, which would mean his cousin, Bellatrix Lestrange."
Without realizing what he was doing, Harry sprang to his feet; the telescope and trainers in his lap rolled across the floor. Bellatrix Lestrange, Sirius's killer, inherit his house?
"No," he said.
"Well, obviously we would prefer that she didn't get it either," said Dumbledore calmly.

'Louis gave it to me,' he explained, tucking away the device. 'Keeps the atmosphere more authentic, you know? Now, let's move.'

Taking her arm, he led Jane down the cobblestones along with their companions, who guarded them from any prying eyes.

importance, for it concerns a visionary. His name was Frank Lloyd Wright, he lived in the city where architecture's future was reimagined, and his influence remains profound to this day. 

You see, I study architectural history, unlike most of my contemporaries." 

Philip Johnson looked very seriously at his apprentice. 

"These innovations seem to me to be linked. The critics may disagree - as you may have heard, overhearing discussions about my new design." 

The apprentice nodded. Silence fell between them again, Johnson pondering his blueprints every now and then. The apprentice felt as though he ought to leave, but his curiosity held him firm. 

"Mr. Johnson?" he said again. 

"Yes?" said Johnson. 

"Er . . . could I ask you about... that famous project I saw in your portfolio?" 

"You could," said Johnson heavily. "I worked on it many times, but some collaborations stand out to me more than others ... particularly now. ..." 

"You know - you know the building you showed me? The one with Mies van der Rohe? Well...was it the design for the Seagram Building?" 

Johnson gave the apprentice a very sharp look. "Has no one ever told you why it became a landmark of modern architecture?" he said. 

The apprentice shook his head, wondering, as he did so, how he could have failed to inquire about this, despite years of admiration.

"Yes, it was the design for the Seagram Building," said Johnson. "Mies provided the visionary elements just like Wright did for his era. He and his collaborators transformed the skyline then, as you know." 

"So, it's still considered iconic?" said the apprentice quietly. 

"Yes," said Johnson, his voice full of a reverence the apprentice had never heard there before. 

"It's a masterpiece. It stands tall in New York City. I believe many architects study it, seeking inspiration for their work."
neighbor_question.answer: Frank Lloyd Wright was a groundbreaking American architect known for designs like the Fallingwater. His legacy is studied extensively in architectural history and he significantly influenced modern architecture, especially in the early to mid-20th century. Philip Johnson and Mies van der Rohe indeed collaborated on the iconic Seagram Building, an important piece in the evolution of modernist architecture.

    'Professor Dumbledore?' Harry said very quietly, for Dumbledore, still staring at the Pensieve, seemed completely lost in thought. 'It . . . did that mean . . . what did that mean?'
    'It meant,' said Dumbledore, 'that the person who has the only chance of conquering Lord Voldemort for good was born at the end of July, nearly sixteen years ago. This boy would be born to parents who had already defied Voldemort three times.'
    Harry felt as though something was closing in on him. His breathing seemed difficult again.
    'It means - me?'
    Dumbledore surveyed him for a moment through his glasses.
    The odd thing, Harry,' he said softly, 'is that it may not have meant you at all. Sybill's prophecy could have applied to two wizard boys, both born at the end of July that year, both of whom had parents in the Order of the Phoenix, both sets of parents having narrowly escaped Voldemort three times. One, of course, was you. The other was Neville Longbottom.'
    'But then . . . but then, why was it my name on the prophecy and not Neville's?'
    The official record was re-labelled after Voldemort's attack on you as a child,' said Dumbledore. 'It seemed plain to the keeper of the Hall of Prophecy that Voldemort could only have tried to kill you because he knew you to be the one to whom Sybill was referring

'I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up and live out the true meaning of its creed: We hold these truths to be self-evident, that all men are created equal.'
    The audience at the Lincoln Memorial fell silent, hanging on each word. Martin Luther King Jr. stood resolute before the crowd.
    'Dr. King?' a young man said quietly, for King, still reflecting on his speech, appeared deep in thought. 'Does that mean . . . what does that mean?'
    'It means,' said King, 'that the promise of equality is yet to be fulfilled, and the struggle is ongoing. Those who fight for civil rights must persist until justice is achieved.'
    The young man felt a sense of determination wash over him. His conviction grew stronger.
    'It means - us?'
    King looked at him with understanding.
    'The remarkable thing,' he said softly, 'is that this call to action is for every individual who believes in justice, equality, and freedom.'
    'But then . . . why is it still so difficult for change to come?'
    'Because,' said King, 'the path to equality is fraught with challenges, but every step forward makes a difference.'
neighbor_question.answer: This text refers to Martin Luther King Jr.'s famous 'I Have a Dream' speech, delivered on August 28, 1963, during the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. The speech emphasized the ongoing struggle for civil rights and the belief in equality for all people.

and watched the old leaders and thinkers frozen in contemplation, reflecting on what he had just considered, and quietly absorbing the atmosphere. He felt a renewed sense of clarity, somehow, now that he was in Albert Einstein's study, ready to discuss the latest scientific breakthrough. John glanced at the shelves behind the desk. 

The worn pages of Einstein's notebook lay open. A glass case next to it displayed a notable medal, the one Einstein received for his contributions to physics. John recognized it instantly, having seen it featured in numerous documentaries. He was drawing inspiration from how it symbolized perseverance in challenging times, when he noticed a glimmer of reflected light, subtly dancing on the glass case. He looked around for the light source and saw a narrow beam reflected brightly from a nearby window, partially ajar. John hesitated, glanced at a photograph of Einstein, then got up, walked across the room, and gently pushed the window open.

A roll of parchment lay there, with intricate drawings along the edges: diagrams and equations that John found complex yet intriguing. The reflected light was cast upon it, like nothing he had analyzed before. He couldn't discern if the subjects were theoretical or experimental. Brightly drawn and continually shifting; it seemed to animate with ideas unfolding and developing. It resembled knowledge made tangible - or thought made visible - John couldn't make up his mind.

He wanted to examine it closer, to grasp its essence, but years of academic discipline told him that diving headfirst into complex research without groundwork was unwise. He therefore carefully adjusted his glasses, glanced around the room hesitantly, looked back at the parchment, and carefully started to analyze.
neighbor_question.answer: John is in Albert Einstein's study, contemplating the atmosphere and the intellectual legacy present there. He finds inspiration and is tempted to explore further, but hesitates, knowing the importance of cautious and well-informed investigation into scientific mysteries.

"That's right."
They trudged up the dark, deserted lane, following the freshly made carriage tracks. Harry looked sideways at Tonks under his cloak. Last year she had been inquisitive (to the point of being a little annoying at times), she had laughed easily, she had made jokes. Now she seemed older and much more serious and purposeful. Was this all the effect of what had happened at the Ministry? He reflected uncomfortably that Hermione would have suggested he say something consoling about Sirius to her, that it hadn't been her fault at all, but he couldn't bring himself to do it. He was far from blaming her for Sirius's death; it was no more her fault than anyone else’s (and much less than his), but he did not like talking about Sirius if he could avoid it. And so they tramped on through the cold night in silence, Tonks's long cloak whispering on the ground behind them.
Having always traveled there by carriage, Harry had never before appreciated just how far Hogwarts was from Hogsmeade Station. With great relief he finally saw the tall pillars on either side of the gates, each topped with a winged boar. He was cold, he was hungry and he was quite keen to leave this new, gloomy Tonks behind. “Alohomora!" he said confidently, pointing his wand at the padlock, but nothing happened.

Harry looked around, I could climb a wall," he suggested.

Nearly everyone in the room followed suit. They murmured her name, as they had murmured Sir David's, and drank to her. But through a gap in the standing figures, it was clear that a few people had remained defiantly in their seats, their glasses untouched.     'Coretta,' said Ralph Abernathy gently, walking over to her. 'Coretta, don't . . .'
    Next second, she was sobbing her heart out on Abernathy's shoulder.
    'Coretta, it was just a photograph,' he said soothingly, patting her on the head. 'Just a photograph . . .'
    'I see him g - g - gone all the time!' Coretta moaned into his shoulder. 'All the t - t - time! I d - d - dream about it . . .'
    Jesse Jackson was staring at the charred edge of the frame where the picture had been. John Lewis was looking at the others, who avoided his gaze. He had a funny feeling Lewis’s determined eyes had followed him all the way out of the room.
    'D - d - don't tell the children,' Coretta was gulping now, mopping her eyes frantically with her cuffs. 'I d - d - don't want them to know . . . being silly . . .'
    Abernathy handed her a handkerchief and she blew her nose.
    'Everyone, I'm so sorry. What must you think of me?' she said shakily. 'Not even able to save a photo . . .'
    'Don't be silly,' said Abernathy, trying to smile.
    'I'm just s - s - so worried,' she said, tears spilling out of her eyes again. 'They’re all in the movement, it'll b - b - be a miracle if we all come through this . . . and his legacy is so important . . . what if something d-d - dreadful happens and we've never m - m - made it right? The support network of fellow activists like Ralph Abernathy was crucial during these challenging times.

Then, three years ago, on a night very like tonight, the Prime Minister had been alone in his office when the portrait had once again announced the imminent arrival of Fudge, who had burst out of the fireplace, sopping wet and in a state of considerable panic. Before the Prime Minister could ask why he was dripping all over the Axminster, Fudge had started ranting about a prison the Prime Minister had never heard of, a man named "Serious" Black, something that sounded like "Hogwarts," and a boy called Harry Potter, none of which made the remotest sense to the Prime Minister.
"...I've just come from Azkaban," Fudge had panted, tipping a large amount of water out of the rim of his bowler hat into his pocket. The Prime Minister rather resented being told to sit down in his own office, let alone offered his own whiskey, but he sat nevertheless. Albert Einstein looked at the equations on the board, pondering deeply. His fellow physicists gathered around, discussing the implications of his latest theory.

The Theory Unfolds

'I’m eager to explore the implications,' Einstein said.
'I’m eager to explore the implications,' the mathematician echoed with enthusiasm.

'The child within us is awakened by discoveries beyond dreams,' said the mathematician in an inspired tone. Einstein felt a nod of appreciation from his colleagues.
'Let’s proceed with caution,' Einstein advised. 'This is just the beginning - '
The mathematician beamed with a contagious smile.

neighbor_question.question: Mahatma Gandhi stood at the edge of the salt flats, pondering the vast expanses before him. As the sun began to dip below the horizon, a voice called out from behind him, 'You must not challenge the empire.' It was a British officer, his voice stern and unwavering. 'This amount of salt is insignificantly small, Gandhi,' continued the officer, pointing at the grains in Gandhi's hand. 'But your actions could incite rebellion.' Gandhi smiled gently, 'We seek justice, not rebellion. We only walked here in hope that our peaceful protest would echo across the land.' At this, the officer’s expression hardened, his patience thinning. 'Your arrogance astounds, Mr. Gandhi,' he retorted, stepping back slightly. 'So you wish us to stand aside while you defy us, while you break our laws like mischievous children?' 'No,' Gandhi replied firmly, 'we stand here with respect, but also with resolve to seek what is unjust.' But it seemed that his words did not quell the rising unease. A commanding officer nearby shouted, 'Such defiance cannot go unpunished!' Cheers erupted among the officers as another shouted, 'Arrest them!' Gandhi, unfazed, responded, 'We come in peace, but we will not stand for oppression. This is our home.' But it seemed no one was willing to listen.
neighbor_question.answer: The scene describes Gandhi's famous Salt March in 1930, a significant event in the Indian struggle for independence. Gandhi led a peaceful demonstration against the salt tax imposed by the British government in India.

Dumbledore tapped a bottle with his wand, the cork flew out, and he tipped the swirling memory into the Pensieve, saying as he did so, "After you, Harry." 
  
Harry got to his feet and bent once more over the rippling silver contents of the stone basin until his face touched them. He tumbled through dark nothingness and landed in a sitting room in front of an immensely fat old lady wearing an elaborate ginger wig and a brilliant pink set of robes that flowed all around her, giving her the look of a melting iced cake. She was looking into a small jeweled mirror and dabbing rouge onto her already scarlet cheeks with a large powder puff, while the tiniest and oldest house-elf Harry had ever seen laced her fleshy feet into tight satin slippers. 
"Hurry up, Hokey!" said Hepzibah imperiously. "He said he'd come at four, it's only a couple of minutes to and he's never been late yet!" 
  
She tucked away her powder puff as the house-elf straightened up. The top of the elf's head barely reached the seat of Hepzibah's chair, and her papery skin hung off her frame just like the crisp linen sheet she wore draped like a toga. 
  
"How do I look?" said Hepzibah, turning her head to admire the various angles of her face in the mirror. 
  
"Lovely, madam," squeaked Hokey. 
  
Harry could only assume that it was down in Hokey’s contract that she must lie through her teeth when asked this question, because Hepzibah Smith looked a long way from lovely in his opinion. 
  
A tinkling doorbell rang and both mistress and elf jumped. 
  
"Quick, quick, he's here, Hokey!" cried Hepzibah

In 1959, a young journalist was watching Fidel Castro, the famous revolutionary leader, deliver a stirring speech at a large public gathering in Havana. 

'Impressive Oratory Skills,' 

Albert was closely observing the colorful banners and fervent crowd reactions when he spotted a detailed history book with an illustration of Castro and the Cuban flag on the cover. 

'Learn about the revolution with this comprehensive guide, featuring key events and pivotal moments in Cuban history. A must-read for political enthusiasts!' 
'It's quite informative,' Albert remarked to his colleague, Mike, while perusing the contents. 

'For that keen interest, Albert,' a voice called from behind, 'you can have a discounted copy!' 

A smiling Carlos, the bookseller, approached them, carrying a stack of similar books in hand. 

'How are you, Mike?' They exchanged greetings. 'And what happened to your arm, Albert?' 

'A minor accident while on assignment,' he replied with a grin. 

'Ah, be careful out there,' said Carlos. 'Here —' 

He handed over a small ointment to Albert, who examined the container cautiously. 

'Dab it on, and the pain should ease within an hour,' Carlos assured him. 'We test all our remedies on ourselves first.' 

Albert looked somewhat skeptical. 'It is effective, right?' he inquired. 

'Absolutely,' Carlos replied confidently. 'Mike, let me show you our latest collection.' 

Mike left Albert treating his arm and followed Carlos to explore a showcase of rare historical documents.

It was not as though he was really surprised, thought Harry, as he wrestled with a thorny vine intent upon throttling him; he had had an inkling that this might happen sooner or later. But he was not sure how he felt about it. ... He and Cho were now too em-barrassed to look at each other, let alone talk to each other; what if Ron and Hermione started going out together, then split up? Could their friendship survive it? Harry remembered the few weeks when they had not been talking to each other in the third year; he had not enjoyed trying to bridge the distance between them. And then, what if they didn't split up? What if they became like Bill and Fleur, and it became excruciatingly embarrassing to be in their presence, so that he was shut out for good? 
"Gotcha!" yelled Ron, pulling a second pod from the stump just as Hermione managed to burst the first one open, so that the bowl was full of tubers wriggling like pale green worms. 
The rest of the lesson passed without further mention of Slughorn's party. Although Harry watched his two friends more closely over the next few days, Ron and Hermione did not seem any different except that they were a little politer to each other than usual.
